tit.e: Arisugawa no Miya Imperial Prince Taruhito
Arisugawa no Miya Imperial Prince Taruhito
Arisugawa no Miya Imperial Prince Taruhito

sen.j: 有栖川宮 熾仁親王（ありすがわのみや たるひとしんのう、天保6年2月19日（1835年3月17日） - 1895年（明治28年）1月15日は、江戸幕末～明治時代の皇族、政治家、軍人。
sen.e: Arisugawa no Miya Imperial Prince Taruhito (March 17th, 1835 - January 15th, 1895) was one of the Imperial family, politician and military officer between the last days of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and Meiji period.

Arisugawa no Miya Imperial Prince Taruhito (March 17th, 1835 - January 15th, 1895) was a member of the Imperial family, a politician, and a military officer between the last days of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and the Meiji period.

Arisugawa no Miya Imperial Prince Taruhito (March 17, 1835 - January 15, 1895) was a member of the Imperial family, a politician, and a military officer between the last days of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and the Meiji period.

sen.j: 官職は任命順に、大宰帥、国事御用掛、政府総裁、東征大総督、兵部卿、福岡藩知事（のちに県知事、県令）、元老院議官（後に議長）、鹿児島県逆徒征討総督、左大臣、陸軍参謀本部長、参謀総長、祭主。
sen.e: His governmental posts were as follows, in the order he was appointed; Dazai no Sotsu, General Affairs Official of the Imperial Household in charge of State affair, the President of the government, the Great Governor-General in charge of the military expedition to the east, Hyobu kyo, the Governor of Fukuoka Province (later Governor of the prefecture, Kenrei (same as governor)), a member of the Chamber of Elders (later became the Chairman), the Governor-General in charge of suppressing the oppositions of Kagoshima Prefecture, the Minister of the Left, the head of the Military General Staff Office, the President of councilor and Lord Custodian [Chief Priest] of the Great Shrine of Ise.
sen.cmt: 国事御用掛→a general affairs official of the Imperial Household in charge of State affair[定訳不明] 東征大総督→the Great Governor-General in charge of the military expedition to the east[定訳不明]

sen.j: 最初の妃は、旧水戸藩主・徳川斉昭の娘、徳川貞子。
sen.e: The first Empress was the head of the former Lord of Mito domain, Nariaki TOKUFAWA's daughter, Sadako TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: しかし、病弱であった貞子は婚儀の2年後、熾仁親王の福岡赴任中に23歳の若さで死去したため、明治6年7月に旧越後新発田藩主・溝口直溥の養女・董子（＝ただこ、伊勢神戸藩嫡子・本多忠穆の娘）と再婚した。
sen.e: Sadako was born weak and died when she was twenty three years old, after two years of the marriage, while Imperial Prince Taruhito was away to Fukuoka, the Prince remarried with the head of the former Lord of Echigo Shibata domain, Naohiro MIZOGUCHI's adopted daughter, Tadako. (Tadako, the oldest son of the Lord of Ise Kobe domain, 本多忠穆's daughter.)

sen.j: 天保6年2月19日、熾仁親王は京都御所北東の有栖川宮邸内において、幟仁親王の第一子として誕生した。
sen.e: He was born in Arisugawa no Miya mansion, located at north east of Kyoto Imperial Palace on February 19th, Tenpo 6, as the first Prince of Prince Takahito.

sen.j: 生母の佐伯祐子は通称を嘉奈といい、若宮八幡宮宮司の佐々祐條の娘であった。
sen.e: His birth mother, Yuko SAEKI was called 嘉奈, she was the chief priest of Wakamiya Hachiman-gu Shrine, 佐々祐條's daughter.

sen.j: 実はこのとき、父である幟仁親王はまだ正室の二条廣子と結婚する前であり、熾仁親王は後の嘉永元年9月（1848年10月）に廣子と養子縁組を行っている。
sen.e: In fact, his father, Imperial Prince Takahito was not married to Hiroko NIJO who was his legal wife, he organized an adoption engagement with Hiroko in October 1848.
In fact, his father, Imperial Prince Takahito was not married to Hiroko NIJO who was his legal wife, he organized an adoption engagement with Hiroko in October 1848.
sen.cmt: if Hiroko NIJO was his legal wife, how could he NOT be married to her? Doesn't make sense.
sen.e: In fact, his father, Imperial Prince Takahito, had not yet married Hiroko NIJO at that time; he organized an adoption engagement with Hiroko in October 1848.
sen.cmt: 婚姻関係を明確に訳し直しました。

sen.j: 熾仁親王の胎盤は当時の風習により、出世稲荷神社の境内に埋められた。
sen.e: The placenta of Imperial Prince Taruhito was put under the ground of Shusse Inari-Jinja Shrine, following the tradition in those days.
The placenta of Imperial Prince Taruhito was put under the grounds of Shusse Inari-Jinja Shrine, following the tradition of those days.

sen.j: お七夜の儀に際し、「歓宮」の幼名を授けられる。
sen.e: He was named 'Yoshino Miya' (name for the small child) at the celebration of the seventh day after birth.
He was named 'Yoshino Miya' (name for a small child) at the celebration of the seventh day after the birth.
He was named 'Yoshino Miya' (name for a small child) at the celebration of the seventh day after the birth.

sen.j: 嘉永元年10月18日（1848年11月13日）、熾仁親王はすでに崩御していた仁孝天皇の猶子となる。
sen.e: He became an adopted son of Emperor Nintoku on November 13th, 1848, who was already passed away.
He became the adopted son of Emperor Nintoku on November 13th, 1848, who was already passed away.
He became the adopted son of Emperor Nintoku on November 13, 1848, who was already passed away.

sen.j: 翌嘉永二年2月14日（1849年3月8日）、孝明天皇より「熾仁」の諱を賜り、2日後の2月16日（3月10日）に親王宣下を受けた。
sen.e: He was given the personal name of 'Taruhito' by Emperor Komei on 8th March 1849, two days after that, he received to title Prince by Imperial order on March 10th.
He was given the personal name of 'Taruhito' by Emperor Komei on the 8th of March 1849, two days after that, he received the title Prince by Imperial order on March 10th.
He was given the personal name of 'Taruhito' by Emperor Komei on March 8, 1849, two days after that, he received the title Prince by Imperial order on March 10.

sen.j: この年の3月15日（4月7日）、熾仁親王は近衛忠煕の加冠により元服し大宰帥に任命、翌日には品位に叙せられた。
sen.e: On April 7th in the same year, Imperial Prince Taruhito had a coming-of-age ceremony and was appointed as Dazai no sochi and received court rank on the following day.
On April 7th in the same year, Imperial Prince Taruhito had a coming-of-age ceremony and was appointed as Dazai no sochi and received court rank on the following day.
On April 7 in the same year, Imperial Prince Taruhito had a coming-of-age ceremony and was appointed as Dazai no sochi and received court rank on the following day.
sen.cmt: 日付表記を修正スペース削除

sen.j: 以後、慶應3年に新政府の総裁三職時代の総裁（明治新政府）職に任命されるまで、熾仁親王は「帥宮（そちのみや）」と呼ばれた。
sen.e: After that the Prince was called 'Sochino Miya' until he was appointed to the President (Meiji new government) of the new government of Sosai Sanchoku period in Keio 3.
After that the Prince was called 'Sochino Miya' until he was appointed to the President (Meiji new government) of the new government in the Sosai Sanchoku period in Keio 3.
After that the Prince was called 'Sochino Miya' until he was appointed to the President (Meiji new government) of the new government in the Sosai Sanchoku period in 1867.

sen.j: 従って、幕末関連の文書で「帥宮様」「帥宮御方」などと書かれているのは全て熾仁親王のことを指す。
sen.e: Thus persons described as 'Sochi no Miya' 'Sochi no Miya onkata' in the historical books related to the last days of bakufu means Imperial Prince Taruhito.
Thus persons described as 'Sochi no Miya' 'Sochi no Miya onkata' in the historical books related to the last days of the bakufu means Imperial Prince Taruhito.
Thus persons described as 'Sochi no Miya' 'Sochi no Miya onkata' in the historical books related to the last days of the bakufu means Imperial Prince Taruhito.

sen.j: 幕末
sen.e: The last days of the bakufu
The last days of the bakufu
The last days of the bakufu

sen.j: 熾仁親王は嘉永4年（1851年）、17歳の時に孝明天皇の皇妹・和宮親子内親王と婚約し、和宮の歌道指南役を務めたりしたが、公武合体策の一環として和宮が徳川家茂と結婚することになり婚約は破棄された。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Taruhito engaged to Emperor Komei's sister, Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Princess Chikako when he was seventeen years old, however it was decided Kazunomiya married to Iemochi TOKUGAWA, as part of the union of the imperial Court and the Shogunate policy, the engagement was cancelled.

Imperial Prince Taruhito was engaged to Emperor Komei's sister, Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Princess Chikako when he was seventeen years old, however it was decided that Kazunomiya marry Iemochi TOKUGAWA, as part of the union of the imperial Court and the Shogunate policy, so, the engagement was cancelled.

Imperial Prince Taruhito was engaged to Emperor Komei's sister, Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako, in 1851 when he was seventeen years old and working as Kazunomiya's instructor in tanka (or waka) poetry; however, it was decided that Kazunomiya would marry Iemochi TOKUGAWA as part of the union of the imperial Court and the Shogunate policy, so the engagement was cancelled.
sen.cmt: 年号補足「和宮の歌道指南役を務めたりしたが」を訳出しました。 The double use of "princess" in "Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Princess Chikako" makes no sense to me. Surely this would be "Imperial Princess Kazunomiya Chikako."

sen.j: 親王はこの事に加え、家臣であり教育係であった飯田忠彦の影響を色濃く受け、明治新政府の成立に至るまで朝廷における反会津・親長州派の急先鋒となった。
sen.e: In addition to above, the Prince was influenced strongly by his aides as well as an educator, Tadahiko IDA, he was the vanguard against Aizu and Choshu domain supporters of the Imperial Palace until the Meiji new government was established.

In addition to the above, the Prince was influenced strongly by his aides as well as an educator, Tadahiko IDA, he was the vanguard against the Aizu and Choshu domain supporters of the Imperial Palace until the Meiji new government was established.

In addition to the above, the Prince was influenced strongly by his aides as well as an educator, Tadahiko IDA, he was the vanguard against the Aizu and Choshu Domain supporters of the Imperial Palace until the Meiji new government was established.

sen.j: これにより、京都に集った尊攘志士はこぞって親王を頼った。
sen.e: Due to this, all the supporters of the doctrine of restoring the emperor (to the power) and expelling the barbarians who gathered to Kyoto relied on the Prince.
Due to this, all the supporters of the doctrine of restoring the emperor to power and expelling the barbarian, who gathered in Kyoto, relied upon the Prince.
Due to this, all the supporters of the doctrine of restoring the emperor to power and expelling the barbarian, who gathered in Kyoto, relied upon the Prince.

sen.j: 特に八月十八日の政変の前後からは、商人を装い「枡屋喜右衛門」を名乗っていた元毘沙門堂家臣・古高俊太郎を仲介者として、寺島忠三郎や久坂玄瑞ら京に残った勤王派の長州藩士達が、粟津義風・前川茂行といった有栖川宮の諸大夫や家臣達と複数回にわたり接触し、両者の間で密会の場を設けたり密使を潜伏させあうなどの交際を行っているほか、熾仁親王は粟津や前川に命じ、長州藩家老の益田兼施宛に慰問の書状を出させたりしている。
sen.e: Especially before and after the political change on August 18th, the warriors of Choshu domain, the people loyal to the Emperor who remained in Kyoto such as Chuzaburo TERAJIMA and Genzui KUSAKA, had contacted with various Taifu of Arisugawanomiya through the former Bishamon do aides, Shutaro FURUTAKA (KOTAKA), who pretended to be a business man and named 'Kiemon MASUYA', they both had secret meeting or exchanged the secret messengers, Prince Taruhito ordered 粟津 and 前川 to send a letter of consolation to the Chief retainer of a feudal lord of Choshu domain, Kanenobu MASUDA.

Especially before and after the political change on August 18th, the samurai of the Choshu domain, people loyal to the Emperor who remained in Kyoto such as Chuzaburo TERAJIMA and Genzui KUSAKA, had contacted various Taifu of Arisugawanomiya through the former Bishamon do aides, Shutaro FURUTAKA (KOTAKA), who pretended to be a business man and named 'Kiemon MASUYA', they both exchanged secret messengers, Prince Taruhito ordered 粟津 and 前川 to send a letter of consolation to the Chief retainer of a feudal lord of Choshu domain, Kanenobu MASUDA.

Especially before and after the political change on August 18, the samurai of the Choshu Domain, people loyal to the Emperor who remained in Kyoto such as Chuzaburo TERAJIMA and Genzui KUSAKA, had contacted various Taifu of Arisugawanomiya or aides many times, such as Yoshikaze AWAZU and Shigeyuki MAEKAWA through the former Bishamon do aides, Shutaro FURUTAKA (KOTAKA), who pretended to be a business man and named 'Kiemon MASUYA,' they had contact by organizing to have a place for secret meeting, or they both exchanged secret messengers in hiding to each others, Prince Taruhito ordered Awazu and Maekawa to send a letter of consolation to the Chief retainer of a feudal lord of Choshu Domain, Kanenobu MASUDA.
sen.cmt: 日付表記を修正domain→Domainスペース削除コンマの位置移動「粟津義風・前川茂行といった有栖川宮の諸大夫や家臣達と複数回にわたり接触し、両者の間で密会の場を設けたり密使を潜伏させあうなどの交際を行っているほか」を訳出しました。

sen.j: 禁門の変の2ヶ月前である元治元年5月9日（1864年6月12日）、熾仁親王は父・幟仁親王とともに国事御用掛に任命されて朝政に参画し、親長州派の立場から京都守護職・松平容保らの幕臣たちや、久邇宮朝彦親王ら佐幕派の皇族・公卿らと対立した。
sen.e: On June 12th, 1864, two months before the Kinmon Incident, Imperial Prince Taruhito and the father, Imperial Prince Takahito were appointed as an officials in charge of national affairs and took part in the planning of the politics in the Imperial Palace, since they were the supporters of the Choshu domain, they opposed against Kyoto Protection official, Katamori MATSUDAURA's close aides and the supporters of the Shogun, Kuni no Miya Imperial Prince Asahito.

On June 12th, 1864, two months before the Kinmon Incident, Imperial Prince Taruhito and his father, Imperial Prince Takahito were appointed as officials in charge of national affairs and took part in the planning politics in the Imperial Palace, since they were supporters of the Choshu domain, they opposed Kyoto Protection official, Katamori MATSUDAURA's close aides and supporters of the Shogun, Kuni no Miya Imperial Prince Asahito.

On June 12, 1864, two months before the Kinmon Incident, Imperial Prince Taruhito and his father, Imperial Prince Takahito were appointed as officials in charge of national affairs and took part in the planning politics in the Imperial Palace, since they were supporters of the Choshu Domain, they opposed Kyoto Protection official, Katamori MATSUDAIRA's close aides and supporters of the Shogun, Kuni no Miya Imperial Prince Asahiko.
sen.cmt: 日付表記を修正人名スペルを修正domain→Domain

sen.j: それから間もない元治元年6月5日（1864年7月8日）、長州藩士と宮家との連絡役であった古高は新撰組に捕縛され、副長・土方歳三の拷問を受けて容保殺害計画や孝明天皇拉致計画、京都市中放火計画などを自白したとされる。
sen.e: Soon after that, on July 8th, 1864, it is said Furutaka, who was the contact person between the Choshu domain and the Miyake, was caught by Shinsengumi and tortured by the Deputy Chief, Toshizo HIJIKATA, Furutaka confessed there was a plan to kill Katamori MATSUDAIRA, or plan to kidnap Emperor Komei, plan to to put fire all over Kyoto city and so on.

Soon after that, on July 8th, 1864, it is said Furutaka, who was the contact person between the Choshu and the Miyake domains, was caught by Shinsengumi and tortured by the Deputy Chief, Toshizo HIJIKATA, Furutaka confessed there was a plan to kill Katamori MATSUDAIRA, or a plan to kidnap Emperor Komei, a plan to to set fire all over Kyoto city, etc.

Soon after that, on July 8, 1864, it is said Furutaka, who was the contact person between the Choshu Domain and the Miyake (house of an imperial prince), was caught by Shinsengumi and tortured by the Deputy Chief, Toshizo HIJIKATA, Furutaka confessed there was a plan to kill Katamori MATSUDAIRA, or a plan to kidnap Emperor Komei, a plan to set fire all over Kyoto city, etc.
sen.cmt: 日付表記を修正Domainの位置移動(families allowed to be in status of Imperial family)補足to重複削除"families allowed to be in status of Imperial family"→"house of an imperial prince"に変更しました。

sen.j: これらのテロ計画に、熾仁親王本人を始め有栖川宮関係者が関知・関与していたか否か今日では証明できていないが、元来長州毛利家と縁戚で自他共に認める尊攘論者だった熾仁親王は、有力な過激派シンパとして容保たちからさらに警戒されるようになる。
sen.e: It can not be proved nowadays whether Prince Taruhito and other Arisugawanomiya related people had something to do with above terrorism or not, since Prince Taruhito was Mori Family of Choshu's relative, and also well known supporter of the Emperor by others as well as by himself, he became being alarmed by Katamori and others as extreme sympathizer.

It can not be proved, nowadays, whether Prince Taruhito and other Arisugawanomiya related people, had something to do with the above terrorism or not, since Prince Taruhito was a relative of the Mori Family of Choshu, and also well known supporter of the Emperor by others, as well as by himself, he became alarmed by Katamori and others as an extreme sympathizer.
sen.cmt: "and also well known supporter of the Emperor by others, as well as by himself, he became alarmed by Katamori and others as an extreme sympathizer." I can not understand what the translator means by this part and particularly "by others, " "himsel," and "he," and "extreme sympathizer,"to who? who is "he?" etc. This needs to be rewritten and the meaning clarified"
sen.e: It can not be proved, nowadays, whether Prince Taruhito and other Arisugawanomiya related people, had something to do with the above terrorism or not, since Prince Taruhito was a relative of the Mori family of Choshu, and also well known supporter of the Emperor by other Imperial members, Prince Taruhito himself admitted it, he became being alarmed by Katamori and his group as an extreme (communist) sympathizer.
sen.cmt: 全体的に原文に沿って訳し直しました。

sen.j: そのため禁門の変が発生した際、熾仁親王は佐幕派から真っ先に長州藩との関係を糾弾された。
sen.e: Therefore, when the Kinmon Incident happened, he was condemned by the Shogun supporters of his relationship with the Choshu Domain.

sen.j: 長州藩士との接触が多かった諸大夫の粟津義風は、彼らに便宜を図っていた容疑で慶応2年（1866年）に至るまで京都町奉行所に逮捕・投獄され、熾仁親王自身も孝明天皇の怒りを買い、幟仁親王とともに国事御用掛を解任され、謹慎・蟄居を申し渡された。
sen.e: The Shodaibu (Samurai who received higher than the Fourth or Fifth Court Rank), 粟津義風, who had often dealt with the Choshu Domain, was arrested and went to the Kyoto City, Magistrate's office under the suspicion of doing favor for Choshu Domain until 1866, Emperor Komei was furious about Prince Taruhito under this circumstances, the Prince lost his position as a general affairs official of the Imperial Household in charge of State affair, and both Prince Taruhito and Takahito were ordered to be refrained from making public appearances and placed in confinement at home.

sen.j: 途中、中川宮や正親町三条実愛らが孝明天皇に幟仁・熾仁両親王の赦免嘆願を上奏したが、孝明天皇はついにその勅勘を解かぬまま崩御した。
sen.e: Once Nakagawa no Miya and Sanenaru Ogimachi-SANJO asked an entreaty for Emperor Komei that Prince Taruhito and Takahito to be pardoned, however the Emperor died without canceling the punishment from the Emperor.

sen.j: 両親王が謹慎生活で外部との接触を絶たれている間、長州征伐、薩長同盟の成立、将軍徳川家茂の死去と徳川慶喜の将軍就任、さらに孝明天皇の崩御により、時代はそれまでとは桁違いの速度で変化してゆく。
sen.e: The situation was changed dramatically compared to before, the Choshu Expeditions happened, the establishment of the Satsuma-Chochu Alliance, the death of Shogun Iemochi TOKUGAWA, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA being new Shogun, the death of Emperor Komei and so on, while the Prince Taruhito and Takahito were refrained from making public appearances and had no contact with outside.

sen.j: しかし、この謹慎期間中も熾仁親王は僧侶に変装して夜な夜な邸を抜け出し、同志たちと密会して国事を論じたほか、入獄中の粟津に代わって頭角を現した藤井希璞（後の元老院議官）を密使として、長州側と接触を図っていたと言われている。
sen.e: However, although the Prince Taruhito was placed in confinement at home, it is said he disguise to be a monk and went out of the house at night, he had a meeting with his fellow members to discuss about national affairs, he also used Kiboku FUJII (later became councilor of senior statement) as a secret messenger, who began to distinguish himself as a new leader after 粟津 was arrested, to contact with Choshu sides.

sen.j: 慶応3年（1867年）1月に明治天皇が践祚すると、幟仁親王・熾仁親王父子は許されて謹慎を解かれた。
sen.e: In January 1867 after Emperor Meiji ascended to the throne, both father and son, Imperial Prince Takahito and Taruhito were forgiven and allowed to show their public appearances.
In January 1867 after Emperor Meiji ascended to the throne, both father and son, Imperial Prince Takahito and Taruhito were forgiven and allowed to appear in public appearances.

sen.j: この頃から再び勤王派の志士が、倒幕完遂の旗印に担ぎ出すべく有栖川宮家に接近を図っている。
sen.e: Since this time, the royalist again approached Arisugawa no Miya under the banner of overthrow the bakufu.
The royalist again approached Arisugawa no Miya urging the overthrow of the bakufu.

sen.j: 当主である父・幟仁親王は謹慎解除後は政治活動から距離をおいたが、明治天皇の信任と倒幕派の人望が篤い熾仁親王は、王政復古のクーデター計画も西郷隆盛等から事前に知らされる。
sen.e: The father, and the head of the family, Imperial Prince Takahito was away from the political activities after he was allowed to show his public appearances, however Emperor Meiji had complete trust in the Imperial Prince Taruhito and other people against the bakufu trusted him as well, Takamori SAIGO and others let the Prince knew about a coup plan of the restoration of imperial rule in advance.

The father, and the head of the family, Imperial Prince Takahito stayed away from political activities after he was allowed to appear in public, however Emperor Meiji had complete trust in Imperial Prince Taruhito and other people who were against the bakufu also trusted him as well, Takamori SAIGO and others let the Prince know about a planned coup, in advance, for the restoration of imperial rule.

sen.j: このクーデターの成功により新政府が樹立され総裁・議定・参与の三職が新たに設けられると、熾仁親王はその最高職である総裁に就任する。
sen.e: This coup was successful and the new government was established, new three positions of the President, Gijo and Councilor were introduced, the Imperial Prince Taruhito became the highest position of the President.

This coup was successful and the new government was established, three new positions of President, Gij, and Councilor were established and the Imperial Prince Taruhito assumed the highest position of President.

sen.j: その直後の慶応4年（1868年）、薩長の度重なる挑発に対し、幕府軍はついに戦端を開き（鳥羽・伏見の戦い）、ここに戊辰戦争が勃発するが、このとき賊軍の首領とされた徳川慶喜は、熾仁親王にとって父・幟仁親王の従弟であった。
sen.e: In 1868, just after that, the bakufu started fighting against Saccho (Satsuma and Choshu domain) after they provoked the bakufu many times (the Toba-Fushimi War), this was the beginning of the Boshin War, the head of this rebel army, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA was the cousin of Imperial Prince Taruhito's father, Imperial Prince Takahito.

sen.e: Therefore, Imperial Prince Taruhito felt shame at his relatives going against the Imperial Palace and he received a charter to become the Great Governor-General in charge of the military expedition to the east by himself.

sen.j: 参謀の西郷隆盛に補佐され官軍は東海道を下って行くが、この東征の旅路も実はのどかなものであり、親王は常に輿に乗って移動し、途中の宿場で馬の遠乗りをしたり、各地の名産品に舌鼓を打ったり、花見や和歌に興じたりする様子が親王自身の日記に書き残されている。
sen.e: The Prince was supported by the staff officer, Takamori SAIGO and the government army was going down the Tokaido, there was a record in Imperial Taruhito's diary that it was a quiet country road to go to the east, the Prince was on the palanquin to move, he went on horse riding to far places at the the stage on a way, or had many nice food which were popular in different places, or enjoyed looking at Cherry blossoms and making poems.

The Prince was supported by a staff officer, Takamori SAIGO and as the government army was advancing down the Tokaido, it was recorded in Imperial Taruhito's diary that it was a quiet country road to the east, the Prince was on the palanquin, he went on horseback, riding to far places along the way, ate many nice foods which were popular in various places, and enjoyed looking at Cherry blossoms and writing poetry.

sen.j: この道中で、熾仁親王は恭順を条件に慶喜を助命する方針を固めており、江戸から東征中止の要請と慶喜の助命嘆願のために訪れた北白川宮能久親王と駿府で会見し、法親王に慶喜の恭順の意思を問うている。
sen.e: On the way to the east, the Prince made up his mind up to spare Yoshinobu's life by sworing allegiance, in Sunpu, he met with Hitashirakawa no Miya Prince Yoshihisa came from Edo, who came to ask for breaking off the attack to the east and to spare Yoshinobu's life, he asked the Hosshinno's (the Prince who went into the priesthood and received a title to become the Prince by the Emperor) opinion about sparing Yoshinobu's life.

On the way east, the Prince made up his mind up to spare Yoshinobu's life by having him swear allegiance, in Sunpu, he met with Hitashirakawa no Miya Prince Yoshihisa from Edo, who came to ask him to break off the attack east and to spare Yoshinobu's life, he asked the Hosshinno's (the Prince who went into the priesthood and received a title to become the Prince by the Emperor) opinion about sparing Yoshinobu's life.

sen.j: 一方で、公現入道親王のもう一つの目的であった東征中止については、熾仁親王はこれを断固拒否した。
sen.e: On the other hand, monk-Prince Kogen's another purpose to ask, to stop the attack to the east was strongly refused by Prince Taruhito.

sen.j: 幸い、東海道において官軍は一度の戦闘もなく江戸に到着し、4月11日（新暦5月3日）江戸城は無血のうちに開城される。
sen.e: Luckily the government army did not have any battle until they reached Edo, the Edo castle was opened on April 11th without having any blood from the fighting.
Luckily the government army did not experience any battles until they reached Edo, the Edo castle was opened on April 11th without any bloodshed.

sen.j: この日、慶喜は死一等を免じられた代わりとして謹慎するため水戸へ発った。

sen.j: この無血開城に勝海舟と共に尽力したのが、熾仁親王のかつての婚約者、静寛院宮（和宮）であった。
sen.e: It was Kaishu KATSU and the former Prince Taruhito's fiancee, Seikan in no Miya (Kazunomiya) who contributed to the opening of the Edo castle without any fighting.

sen.e: After just arriving at Edo, the system of the Grand Council of State was established and the Sanshoku (a president, a Gijo, a counselor) was abolished, the Prince's position as the President was not valid any longer.

sen.j: 明治10年（1877年）の西南戦争では鹿児島県逆徒征討総督に就任し、維新に際して共に国事を語らい、東征に際して共に官軍を指揮した西郷隆盛と、敵将として対峙する皮肉な立場に立った。
sen.e: He became the Governor-General in charge of suppressing the oppositions of Kagoshima Prefecture at the Seina War in 1877, ironically he opposed to Takamori SAIGO who used to discuss national affairs each others at the Meiji Restoration, or command the national army together at the expedition on the east.

sen.j: 西南戦争における功により、同年10月10日に隆盛に次いで史上二人目の陸軍大将に任命され、11月2日には大勲位菊花大綬章を受章した。
sen.e: Due to his achievement at the Seinan War, he was appointed as the Military General, second person in the history, he received the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum on 2nd November.

Due to his achievements in the Seinan War, he became only the second person in history to be appointed to the position of Rikugun Taisho (Military General), and received the Grand Cordon of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum on November 2.
sen.cmt: 日付表記を修正「史上2人目」は「大勲位菊花大綬章を受章した」ではなく「陸軍大将に任命され」にかかりますので、そのように訳出しました。

sen.j: 西南戦争のさなか、佐野常民や大給恒から「博愛社」（後の日本赤十字社）設立の建議を受けるが、官軍のみならず逆徒である薩軍をも救護するその精神を熾仁親王は嘉し、中央に諮る事なくこれを認可した。
sen.e: During the Seinan War, he received a proposal to establish 'Hakuai sha' (later called the Japanese Red Cross Society) by Tsunetami SANO and Yuzuru OGYU, he approved it without consulting the main government, as he was moved to the spirit to rescue not only the government army but also to help the oppositions, Satsuma army.

sen.j: その後熾仁親王は、時の皇族の第一人者として明治天皇から絶大な信任を受けた。
sen.e: After that Imperial Prince Taruhito had a absolute trust from the Emperor Meiji as a recognized authority on Imperial family in those days.

sen.e: In 1882, he participated to the enthronement ceremony of Alexander Ⅲ held at the capital city of Russia Empire, Sankt-Peterburg; Saint Petersburg representing the Emperor, on a way coming back to Japan, he made a round of visits to European countries and United States.

sen.j: 明治27年（1894年）に勃発した日清戦争では陸海軍の総司令官として広島大本営に下るが、腸チフス（当初はマラリアと診断された）を発症し、兵庫県の有栖川宮舞子別邸にて静養に入る。
sen.e: He came down to Hiroshima Imperial Headquarters as the supreme commander of military and navy in the Sion-Jaoanese War occurred in 1894, however he became ill of typhoid fever (it was called malaria at that time), he went to Arisunogawa no Miya Maiko villa in Kyogo Prefecture to rest.

He went down to Hiroshima Imperial Headquarters as the supreme commander of the military and navy in the Sion-Jaoanese War that occurred in 1894, however he became down with typhoid fever (it was called malaria at that time), and went to Arisunogawa no Miya Maiko villa in Kyogo Prefecture to rest.

He went down to Hiroshima Imperial Headquarters as the supreme commander of the military and navy in the Sino-Japanese War that occurred in 1894, however he came down with typhoid fever (he was initially diagnosed as having malaria), and went to Arisunogawa no Miya Maiko villa in Kyogo Prefecture to rest.
sen.cmt: 「当初はマラリアと診断された」の意味を訳文に反映しました。「初めはマラリアを診断されたが、実は腸チフスだった」という意味に解釈しました。

sen.j: 症状は一旦軽快したものの翌明治28年（1895年）に入って再び悪化し、1月14日にはついに危篤に陥る。
sen.e: He was getting better but in 1895 he became sick again, he was in the serious condition on 14th January.
He was getting better but in 1895 became sick again, he was in the serious condition by 14th of January.
He was getting better but in 1895 became sick again, he was in the serious condition by January 14.

sen.j: その知らせを受けた明治天皇はこの日、熾仁親王への大勲位菊花章頸飾授与を決定した。
sen.e: After Emperor Meiji heard this news, he decided to conferment the Collor of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum to Imperial Prince Taruhito.
After Emperor Meiji heard this news, he decided to confer the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum to Imperial Prince Taruhito.
sen.cmt: "Collor" is not understood and was deleted
sen.e: After Emperor Meiji heard this news, he decided to confer the Collar of the Supreme Order of the Chrysanthemum to Imperial Prince Taruhito.

sen.j: 翌1月15日、熾仁親王は終戦を待たずして舞子別邸にて61歳で薨去。
sen.e: On the following day, 15th January, it was before the end of the War, Imperial Prince Taruhito died in Maiko villa when he was sixty one years old.
On the following day, 15th of January, just before the end of the War, Imperial Prince Taruhito died in Maiko villa when he was sixty one years old.
On the following day, January 15, just before the end of the War, Imperial Prince Taruhito died in Maiko villa when he was sixty one years old.

sen.j: さらに翌16日には功二級金鵄勲章が授与されたが、これを生前に授与されたことにする等の事情により、公式発表における薨去の日付は、実際には遺体が東京に帰着した日である24日と発表された。
sen.e: Furthermore, on the following day, 16th January, he was given a medal for merit of 功二級 Golden Pheasant, as it was organized the medal was supposed to be given before he died, the official announcement of the date of his death was twenty fourth, which was the day his body arrived to Tokyo.
sen.cmt: 功二級金鵄勲章→[定訳不明] 功二級→読み方確認できず
sen.e: Furthermore, on the following day, January 16th, he was given the medal of merit 功二級 Golden Pheasant, as the medal was supposed to have been given before he died, the official announcement of the date of his death was the 24th, which was the day his body arrived in Tokyo.

Furthermore, on the following day, January 16, he was given the medal of merit 功二級 Golden Pheasant, as the medal was supposed to have been given before he died, the official announcement of the date of his death was the 24th, which was the day his body arrived in Tokyo.

sen.j: 熾仁親王の葬儀は国葬となり、豊島岡墓地内の有栖川宮家墓所に埋葬された。
sen.e: The state funeral was organized for the Imperial Prince Taruhito, and he was buried in Arisugawa no Miya cemetery within Toshima ga oka Ceremony.
A state funeral was organized for Imperial Prince Taruhito, and he was buried in Arisugawa no Miya cemetery with a Toshima ga oka Ceremony.
A state funeral was organized for Imperial Prince Taruhito, and he was buried in Arisugawa no Miya cemetery with a Toshima ga oka Ceremony.

sen.j: 家族
sen.e: The Family
The Family
The family
sen.cmt: 文頭以外の語頭を小文字に

sen.j: 親王は貞子・董子どちらの妃との間にも王子女に恵まれなかったため、慣例に従うなら別の宮家を創設するか臣籍降下するはずであった異母弟の有栖川宮威仁親王を、自身の後継者にすることが生前に明治天皇から許されていた。
sen.e: The Prince did not have any children either with Sadako nor Tadako, it was approved by the Emperor Meiji before he died, to have his half younger brother, Arisunogawa no Miya Imperial Prince Takehito as a successor to him, who was supposed to establish new princely house or to demote from nobility to subject according to the custom.

The Prince did not have any children either with Sadako nor Tadako, it was approved by Emperor Meiji before he died, to have his half younger brother, Arisunogawa no Miya Imperial Prince Takehito as his successor, who was supposed to have established a new palace or have been demoted from nobility to subject according to custom.

The Prince did not have any children either with Sadako nor Tadako, it was approved by Emperor Meiji before he died, to have his half younger brother, Arisunogawa no Miya Imperial Prince Takehito as his successor, who was supposed to have established a new Miyake or have been demoted from nobility to subject according to custom.

sen.j: これにより、熾仁親王の薨去後は威仁親王が有栖川宮家を継いだ。
sen.e: Due to this after Imperial Prince Taruhito died, Imperial Prince Takehito succeeded to Arisunogawa no Miya family.
Due to this, after Imperial Prince Taruhito died, Imperial Prince Takehito succeeded to the Arisunogawa no Miya family.
Due to this, after Imperial Prince Taruhito died, Imperial Prince Takehito succeeded to the Arisunogawa no Miya family.

sen.j: その他
sen.e: Others
Other
Other

sen.j: 官軍の軍歌であるトコトンヤレ節（品川弥二郎の作詞とされ、「宮さん宮さん」との別名もある）の「宮さん宮さん お馬の前に ひらひらするのは なんじゃいな」と歌詞の中で言われている「宮さん」とは、熾仁親王のことである。
sen.e: In the War song of the government army, Tokoton yare bushi, (it is presumed the song was made by Yajiro SHINAGWA, it has different name of 'Miya san Miya san) it says, 'Miya san Miyasa, what is fluttering in front of the horse', this 'Miya san' in the song means Prince Taruhito.

In the War song of the government army, Tokoton yare bushi, (it is presumed to be a song written by Yajiro SHINAGWA, as it has the different name of 'Miya san Miya san) it says, 'Miya san Miyasa, what is fluttering in front of the horse,' this 'Miya san' in the song means Prince Taruhito.

In the War song of the government army, Tokoton yare bushi, (it is presumed to be a song written by Yajiro SHINAGAWA, as it has the different name of 'Miya san Miya san') it says, 'Miya san Miya san, what is fluttering in front of the horse,' this 'Miya san' in the song means Prince Taruhito.

sen.j: 陸軍の軍人らしく、趣味は馬術と狩猟、そして刀剣のコレクションであった。
sen.e: As he was a militaly officer, his hobby was horse riding and hunting, collecting swords.
As he was a militaly officer, his hobby was horse riding and hunting, and collecting swords.
As he was a military officer, his hobby was horse riding and hunting, and collecting swords.

sen.j: そのほか、園芸・陶芸・竹細工の製作も好んだ。
sen.e: He also liked craft making, pottery, making bamboo craft.
He also liked craft making, pottery, and making bamboo craft.
He also liked craft making, pottery, and making bamboo craft.

sen.j: また、書道・歌道も歴代当主同様名人とされており、前述の通り和宮の歌道指南をしたほか、父幟仁親王より「有栖川流書道」の奥義相伝を受けている。
sen.e: He was also known as a talented calligrapher and poet, same like original head of the successive family, as it was mentioned before, he taught the art of tanka poetry to Kazunomiya, he received an inheritance of secret lore of 'Arisunogawa no Miya style calligraphy' from his father, Imperial Prince Takahito.

He was also known as a talented calligrapher and a poet, like the original head of the successive family, as mentioned before, he taught the art of tanka poetry to Kazunomiya, he received an inheritance of the secret lore of 'Arisunogawa no Miya style calligraphy' from his father, Imperial Prince Takahito.

He was also known as a talented calligrapher and a poet, like the original head of the successive family, as mentioned before, he taught the art of tanka poetry to Kazunomiya, he received an inheritance of the secret lore of 'Arisunogawa no Miya style calligraphy' from his father, Imperial Prince Takahito.

sen.j: 熾仁親王は粗食家で偏食がなく（東征中も官軍兵士と同じ食事を取った）酒量も少なかったが、比較的低い身長に対して体重は十八貫（約68kg）を下回ることはなく、晩年は肥満から来る心臓疾患に悩まされていたといわれる。
sen.e: Imperial Prince Taruhito lived on humble fare and liked almost any kind of foods,(he ate same food as other soldiers of the government army), he did not drink large amount of alcohol, however his weight was always above sixty eight kilogram although he was rather short, he suffered from heart disease caused by being overweight in his late years.

Imperial Prince Taruhito lived on humble fare and liked almost any kind of food, (he ate the same food as other soldiers of the government army), he did not drink large amounts of alcohol, however his weight was always above sixty eight kilograms although he was rather short, he suffered from heart disease caused by being overweight in his later years.

Imperial Prince Taruhito lived on humble fare and liked almost any kind of food, (he ate the same food as other soldiers of the government army), he did not drink large amounts of alcohol, however his weight was always above sixty eight kilograms although he was rather short, he suffered from heart disease caused by being overweight in his later years.

sen.j: 銅像
sen.e: The statue
The statue
The statue

sen.j: 熾仁親王の薨去後、大山巌・山県有朋・西郷従道などが親王の銅像を建立することを提唱し、陸海軍人や一般から資金を募り東京・三宅坂の参謀本部の正門前に親王の騎馬像が建立された。
sen.e: After Imperial Prince taruhito passed away, Iwao Oyama, Aritomo YAMAGATA and Tsugumichi SAIGO suggested to build a statue of his, they collected the donations from soldiers, sailors, and ordinary people, the Prince's statue on the horse was built in front of the main gate of the staff office in Miyakezaka in Tokyo.

After Imperial Prince taruhito passed away, Iwao Oyama, Aritomo YAMAGATA and Tsugumichi SAIGO suggested to build a statue of him, they collected the donations from soldiers, sailors, and ordinary people, the Prince's statue on horseback was built in front of the main gate of the staff office in Miyakezaka, Tokyo.

After Imperial Prince taruhito passed away, Iwao Oyama, Aritomo YAMAGATA and Tsugumichi SAIGO suggested to build a statue of him, they collected the donations from soldiers, sailors, and ordinary people, the Prince's statue on horseback was built in front of the main gate of the staff office in Miyakezaka, Tokyo.

sen.j: 除幕式には、董子妃や威仁親王夫妻、提唱者の元老たちに加え、因縁の深かった徳川慶喜も列席して祝辞を述べている。
sen.e: At the unveiling ceremony, in addition to Empress Tadako, Imperial Prince Takehito and Princess, other old people who were the man who were the proposes, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA who had close relationship to the Prince came and made speeches.

At the unveiling ceremony, in addition to Empress Tadako, Imperial Prince Takehito and Princess, other old people who proposed the stature be built, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA who had a close relationship to the Prince came and made speeches.

At the unveiling ceremony, in addition to Empress Tadako, Imperial Prince Takehito and Princess, other old people who proposed the statue be built, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA who had a close relationship to the Prince came and made speeches.

sen.j: この像は太平洋戦争後、道路拡張工事に伴って東京都港区の有栖川宮記念公園（威仁親王時代の御用地跡）に移設されている。
sen.e: After the Pacific War, as there was a construction work to widen the road, the statue was relocated to Arisunogawa no Miya memorial park (the former Imperial land of Imperial Prince Takehito's) in Minato-ku, Tokyo.

After the Pacific War, as there was a construction work to widen the road, the statue was relocated to Arisunogawa no Miya memorial park (the former Imperial land of Imperial Prince Takehito) in Minato-ku, Tokyo.

sen.j: 昭和4年（1929年）8月、高松宮家によって『熾仁親王印譜』が編集・刊行されている。
sen.e: In August 1929, "Impu (collection of impressions of seals) of Prince Taruhito was edited and published by Takamatsu no Miya Family.

In August 1929, "Inpu (collection of impressions of seals) of Prince Taruhito" was edited and published by the Takamatsu no Miya Family.

sen.j: 篆刻家の中村水竹・細川林斎・羽倉可亭・中井敬所等の印章が93顆収録されている。
